Comment: Polls are only as good as the people conducting them. I don't know what poll you're talking about referring to violence, but that's kind of an oddball thing to ask and guessing it wasn't the most reputable poll (though I am not sure).   But as far as samples go, 1k is a generally pretty decent sample, for a good/reputable pollster. As you can imagine the results you actually see are not just the raw data, because you'd have to just luck into a representative sample by coincidence. Instead they probe the demographics of the people polled, and demographics of the larger populous, and weight results based on who answered.   It's still not perfect by any means. All polls have a margin of error, which is also estimated by the pollster based again on who actually responded. But 1k+ is typically enough for a good pollster to have some results that make sense.   And again want to stress they're never perfect, and also attitudes shift by the day and by the week so even at best a poll is like a snapshot of the "vibes" at the time the poll was taken. And notoriously polls are not very "quick" to capture trends -- the "vibes" in a poll tend to lag behind by at least a week or more.
Author: SirDiego

Comment: With polls and sample sizes, there is a point where adding thousands of more respondents won't significantly change anything.    Think of it like flipping a coin, it should work out to 50/50 odds of it being either heads or tails.  If you only flip the coin 4 times, maybe it comes up heads 3 times and tails 1 time.  If you flip that coin 100 times, it will be right around 50 heads and 50 tails, say 52 heads and 48 tails.  Now do it 900 more times for 1000 total flips and it will be really close to 50/50.  Do you need to flip the coin 9000 more times to see if it's actually 50/50 or would something like 505 to 495 let you say that the chances of flipping a coin are probably 50/50.  That's how sample sizes work.  They need to be large enough to be representative of the population, which for nation wide polling (in a lot of circumstances and assuming the population is representative) is around 1000.  Need more people if you are looking to drill down further or further classify how certain groups feel about the question you're asking.

Comment: Statistical methodology can make for fairly accurate representative polling.  The math can be quite accurate for reputable pollsters.  Meta-analysis can help account for Biased Polling as well ( -- synthesis of quantitative data from multiple independent polls. An important part of this method involves computing a combined effect size across all of the studies )  [Pew Research - Does public opinion polling about issues still work? ](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2022/09/21/does-public-opinion-polling-about-issues-still-work/)  The article analyses Pew's methods and accuracy pretty comprehensively, and use Govt data to check their results ( mostly accurate to hard data within 3 -  5 % with a few exceptions listed ).  >But elections are just one of many topics that polls are used to understand. A new analysis from Pew Research Center examines the accuracy of polling on more than 20 topics, ranging from Americans‚Äô employment and vaccination status to whether they‚Äôve served in the military or experienced financial hardship.  >Consistent with past research, polling errors are larger for some topics ‚Äì like political engagement ‚Äì that may be related to a person‚Äôs willingness to take surveys  There's been several polls showing Disapproval of Tariffs, Inflation, and the Economy  [Forbes - Several Polls Listed to cross-check accuracy ( if you are inclined to check other polls )](https://www.forbes.com/sites/saradorn/2025/04/23/trump-approval-rating-tracker-worst-economic-reviews-in-years-latest-poll-finds/)  **Reuters Poll -  Apr 23**  >Trump‚Äôs handling of the economy received a net -14 Approval rating (37% to 51%), better than Biden‚Äôs 34% economic approval rating in December, but below Trump‚Äôs worst economic approval rating (44%) during his first term  >Disapproval Numbers on Economy  >**Cost of Living - 57% Disapprove**  >**Economy - 51%**  >**International Trade - 52%**  **Mass Poll - Apr 14**  >Trump received his Worst Approval rating of six issues the poll asked about on inflation (33%), followed by trade (36%), civil rights (36%), jobs (38%), foreign affairs (39%) and immigration (50%).  >Disapproval Numbers on Economy  >**Inflation - 62% Disapprove**  >**Trade - 58%**  >**Jobs - 53%**
Author: SurprisedJerboa
